ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Rather than using text/html or XML for IPC, would it be reasonable to use some kind of serialised-SAX format (or make up one if it doesn't exist yet) to avoid all the limitations of HTML and XML parsers?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, it could be part of the given name too
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:29): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: well, given that XML parsers exist and an XML5 parser might exist, inventing yet another infoset serialization seems silly

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:33): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: But XML parsers won't work, since they'll turn most pages into a single "fatal error: XML is not well-formed because of this thing here" message when the validator should instead try to identify as many errors as possible
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: wouldn't XML5 fix that?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:34): XML5 doesn't exist
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:34): some kind of serialised-SAX format doesn't either
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:35): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yeah but the options are making XML5 exist or making yet another SAX serialization exist
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:35): XML5 is arguably more defined than the "some kind of serialised-SAX format
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:35): "

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): XML5 is harder to bring into existence than some other totally-new unconstrained format, because it has to work within the limitations of being compatible with XML 1.0

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:38): and it's not that hard to define and parse some format like <element loc="1:1-2:20"><name>html</name><attribute><name>oops<char code="0c"/></name><value>that wasn't XML</value></attribute></element>
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (14:43): Couldn't you use something like the sdl thing that zcorpan developed?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:45): (http://simon.html5.org/specs/sdf )
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:48): That doesn't really exist either :-)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:59): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: from a parsing point of view, the easiest format would be a binary format which had an opcode for each event followed by known fields
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:59): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: string would be 32-bit lenth followed by UTF-16BE data
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:07): It's more likely we see XML5 getting adoption than any of the named alternatives...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:07): (Though for testcase purposes SDF is obviously preferable.)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:08): Adoption doesn't matter, since this is private communication between two programs written by the same people
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:09): (and since widespread adoption in the future is not helpful when you want an implementation now)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:17): SDF is unsuitable for serialising arbitrary DOMs, since worst-case behaviour is that the minimal SDF representation has size O(n^2) in the size of the DOM
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:17): (for a document like <x><x><x><x><x>....</x>...)
